entry.et: Middle English sclave, from Anglo-French or Medieval Latin; Anglo-French esclave, from Medieval Latin sclavus, from Sclavus Slavic; from the frequent enslavement of Slavs in central Europe during the early Middle Ages

def.dt: :a person held in servitude as the chattel of another
:one that is completely subservient to a dominating influence
:a device (as the printer of a computer) that is directly responsive to another
:to make directly responsive to another mechanism
river 258 miles (415 kilometers) Canada flowing from W end of Lake Athabasca N into Great Slave Lake
:an ant that attacks the colonies of ants of other species and carries off the larvae and pupae to be reared in its own nest as slave workers
:a state of the United States in which slavery was legal until the Civil War
:the buying and selling of blacks for profit prior to the American Civil War
region W Africa bordering on Bight of Benin between Benin & Volta rivers
:a person dependent on wages or a salary for a livelihood
:a woman or girl held unwillingly for purposes of commercial prostitution
